Together? Biomass.
Rot; Craved For In Times Of Scale Trees;
Our Planet's Biosphere Gifting Us Oil,
With Which To Kill Ourselves Via Greenhouse Effect.
Poems?
Just Chaff.
Thousands As Fertilizer.
But For People,
Not Plants.

That's why everyone needs to think it through for themselves. These are the facts:  Nature makes 97% of the CO2.  H2O is by far the most abundant greenhouse gas.  Satellites have not detected any temperature rise in our upper atmosphere where the greenhouse effect is supposed to be happening.  Etc.

author: Nicole Sharp

author: Brimley
text: Farmers let their crops die in the field sometimes. Crops cost money to harvest and if harvesting becomes cost prohibitive they won‚Äôt do it. If it is insured, after it is marked as a crop failure, the circle of life happens: It gets tilled back into the earth and plowed into a new field.

It was precisely due to the failure of one crop.

The reason poor Irish were so dependent on small plots of potatoes was because of British imperialism. 

But it was a crop failure and a famine. Period.

Also, the people who had/have to watch their family starve don't really care about terminology.

author: Ginsu ‚ò≠üîª
text:
The word "famine" evokes a notion that a place is incapable of feeding itself, typically thought to be due to crop failure. This isn't what was killing Ireland....England was.

It's disingenuous, as is saying Palestine is experiencing a "famine." They're being starved as part of a genocide.

author: Ed Carr
text:
I've spent 25 years working with smallholders in rainfed systems.

Repeated crop failure is certainly bad (I work on breadbasket failure too). 

In some places, this will be a real problem. But not yet in the majority of places - or even a plurality of places.

Practically it is true, farmers operate on very tight margins.  It is not feasible for them to suffer repeated frequent crop failure and survive.  It may be technically feasible to grow crops but predictability matters.

Trump says he will put a 25% tariff on all goods coming in the US effective March 4/25. Hey Canada, let‚Äôs completely cut off water and potash from going into the United States and give that orange piece of shit the biggest crop failure in history!! Next let‚Äôs stop all shipping of oil and power

author: Australian Academy of Science
text: The IUCN Red List of Ecosystems and Global Ecosystem Typology provide a global standard for classifying ecosystems and assessing their risk of collapse, giving governments, NGOs, and scientists a vital tool to identify those most at risk.

They‚Äôre obviously intertwined.  

20 years ago the lab I was in was studying dizzying changes in our study ecosystem due to climate change, and another lab mate was watching her entire study system permanently collapse over about 5 years.  Her pop gen study turned into a regional extinction study.

FWIW, I think the ecologists I know (myself included), have been pretty clear we expect things to be very bad.  We‚Äôve mostly felt like people are ignoring the possibly equally consequential biodiversity and ecosystem collapse crisis due to the simpler to explain climate crisis.

author: Jocelyn Perry

And catch us all at COP30 in Bel√©m if you'll be around! Ayoo Irene Hellen will speak alongside the UN High Commissioner for Refugees on an excellent panel tomorrow, and Qiyamud Din will speak on an official side event on the 18th.

author: Jocelyn Perry
text: So what else is needed to move the needle? ACCESS, INFORMATION, and RESOURCES are critical components for meaningful leadership by refugees in climate action: to ACCESS spaces where decisions are made, have all necessary INFO to contribute informed opinions, and have RESOURCES to support themselves.

author: Jocelyn Perry
text:
Yet refugees and other displaced communities are excluded in climate planning processes and actions, from local disaster responses to national adaptation planning and international processes like COPs and the International Migration Review Forum
(See us www.refugeesinternational.org/reports-brie...)

author: Jocelyn Perry
text: We have evidence that refugees are highly exposed to the impacts of climate change, including severe weather, and are often more vulnerable to these impacts because of restrictions on their right to movement, work, shelter (see: @sonjafransen.bsky.social et al. pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC...).

author: Jocelyn Perry
text: Our key message is that refugee voices are excluded from key decision-making spaces related to climate change, but their leadership is crucial for the creation of fair and effective policies. We focus on the spaces we know best: from refugees living in Uganda and Pakistan, to at the UNFCCC processes

author: Jocelyn Perry
text: New piece out in @fmreview.bsky.social's "Climate change: Choices for displaced people"! It seems that these massive gradients also occur now more often in the SH,as the circulation gets as fucked up as in the NH

Antarctic heatwaves the last years and see ice losses are strong indications that this should happen, as they are as much a result as a cause of zonal circulation disturbances

European summer heatwaves are worsening unevenly
